what-is-web-development.title: What is Web Development?
what-is-web-development.intro: Web development is the work involved in building and maintaining websites. It's one of the most in-demand skills in tech, and the best part? You can start learning today with just a computer and an internet connection.

sections.heading: Frontend vs Backend vs Full Stack
sections.content:
Web development is typically divided into three areas:

**Frontend Development** (what users see)
- HTML, CSS, JavaScript
- React, Vue, Angular frameworks
- User interfaces and interactions

**Backend Development** (behind the scenes)
- Server-side programming (Node.js, Python, etc.)
- Databases and data storage
- APIs and server logic

**Full Stack Development**
- Combines both frontend and backend
- Can build complete applications
- Highly versatile and in-demand

sections.heading: Why Learn Web Development?
sections.content:
Web development offers incredible opportunities:

- **High demand**: Every company needs web developers
- **Remote-friendly**: Work from anywhere in the world
- **Creative expression**: Build your ideas into reality
- **Low barrier to entry**: No degree required to get started
- **Great salary**: Average US salary is $80,000+ for entry-level

Whether you want to build your own startup, freelance, or work at a tech company, web development skills open doors.

sections.heading: What You'll Learn in This Course
sections.content:
This course will take you from zero to building real websites:

1. **HTML**: Structure your content
2. **CSS**: Style and design your pages
3. **JavaScript**: Add interactivity
4. **Projects**: Build a portfolio to showcase your skills

By the end, you'll have multiple projects to show employers and the confidence to keep learning.

how-the-web-works.title: How the Web Works
how-the-web-works.intro: Before you build websites, it helps to understand how they actually work. When you type a URL into your browser and hit enter, a fascinating series of events happens in milliseconds.

sections.heading: The Request-Response Cycle
sections.content:
Every website interaction follows this pattern:

1. **You type a URL** (like www.google.com)
2. **DNS lookup**: Your computer asks "What's the IP address for this domain?"
3. **Request sent**: Your browser sends a request to that server
4. **Server responds**: The server sends back HTML, CSS, and JavaScript files
5. **Browser renders**: Your browser turns those files into a visual webpage

This all happens in under a second!

sections.heading: Understanding URLs
sections.content:
A URL (Uniform Resource Locator) has several parts:

`https://www.example.com/products/shoes?color=red`

- **https**: The protocol (secure connection)
- **www.example.com**: The domain name
- **/products/shoes**: The path to a specific page
- **?color=red**: Query parameters (extra information)

Understanding URLs helps you build better navigation and links.

sections.heading: Clients and Servers
sections.content:
**Client**: Your browser (Chrome, Firefox, Safari)
- Requests information
- Displays the website
- Runs JavaScript code

**Server**: A computer that hosts websites
- Stores website files
- Processes requests
- Sends responses

As a frontend developer, you'll mainly write code that runs on the client (browser).

setting-up-your-environment.title: Setting Up Your Development Environment
setting-up-your-environment.intro: Before you write your first line of code, you need the right tools. The good news? Everything you need is free, and setup takes just a few minutes.

sections.heading: Choosing a Code Editor
sections.content:
A code editor is where you'll write your code. We recommend **Visual Studio Code (VS Code)**:

- **Free** and open source
- **Huge ecosystem** of extensions
- **Built-in terminal** and Git support
- **Used by most developers** (great for learning)

Download it at: https://code.visualstudio.com/

Other good options: Sublime Text, Atom, or even Notepad++ for simplicity.

sections.heading: Essential VS Code Extensions
sections.content:
Install these extensions to supercharge your workflow:

1. **Live Server**: Preview your website as you code
2. **Prettier**: Automatically format your code
3. **Auto Rename Tag**: Rename HTML tags easily
4. **HTML CSS Support**: Better autocomplete for CSS

To install: Click the Extensions icon (four squares) in VS Code and search for each one.

sections.heading: Your Browser's Developer Tools
sections.content:
Every modern browser has built-in developer tools:

**How to open them:**
- Right-click on any webpage → "Inspect"
- Or press F12 (Windows) / Cmd+Option+I (Mac)

**Key tabs:**
- **Elements**: See and edit HTML/CSS
- **Console**: See JavaScript errors and logs
- **Network**: Watch files load

Chrome DevTools is the most popular, but Firefox's tools are also excellent.

sections.heading: Creating Your Project Folder
sections.content:
Organization matters from day one:

1. Create a folder called `web-projects` on your computer
2. Inside, create a folder called `my-first-site`
3. Open VS Code and drag this folder into it
4. Create a new file called `index.html`

You're now ready to write your first webpage!

your-first-webpage.title: Creating Your First Webpage
your-first-webpage.intro: It's time to write real code! In this lesson, you'll create your very first webpage and see it in your browser. By the end, you'll understand the basic structure every webpage needs.

sections.heading: The Basic HTML Template
sections.content:
Every webpage starts with this structure: ```html My First Webpage

Hello, World!

This is my first webpage.

``` Type this into your `index.html` file (or copy-paste to start).

sections.heading: Understanding Each Part
sections.content: Let's break down what each part does: - ``: Tells the browser this is HTML5 - ``: The root element containing everything - ``: Metadata (not visible on the page) - ``: The text in the browser tab - `<body>`: Everything visible on the page - `<h1>`: A main heading - `<p>`: A paragraph of text Notice how tags come in pairs: `<body>` opens, `</body>` closes.

sections.heading: Viewing Your Webpage
sections.content:
Two ways to see your page:

**Method 1: Open the file directly**
- Find your `index.html` file
- Double-click to open in browser
- Refresh manually after changes

**Method 2: Use Live Server (recommended)**
- Right-click in VS Code
- Select "Open with Live Server"
- Page auto-refreshes when you save!

Try changing the text in `<h1>` and watch it update.

sections.heading: Mini Project: About Me Page
sections.content:
Practice what you've learned! Create a simple "About Me" page with: 1. A main heading with your name 2. A paragraph about yourself 3. What you want to learn in web development Don't worry about making it pretty yet - that's what CSS is for. Focus on getting the structure right. Example: ```html

Hi, I'm Sarah!

I'm learning web development to build my own apps.

I'm excited to learn HTML, CSS, and JavaScript!

```

text-and-headings.title: Text, Headings & Paragraphs
text-and-headings.intro: Text is the foundation of most websites. HTML provides specific elements for different types of text content, from main headlines to small print. Using the right elements helps both users and search engines understand your content.

links-and-images.title: Links, Images & Media
links-and-images.intro: The web is built on connections. Links let users navigate between pages, and images make content visually engaging. These are two of the most important HTML elements you'll use.

sections.heading: Creating Links
sections.content: The anchor tag `` creates links: ```html Go to Google About Us Jump to Contact Google (new tab) Email Us ``` The `href` attribute specifies the destination.

sections.heading: Adding Images
sections.content: The `` tag embeds images: ```html ``` **Important:** Always include `alt` text! - Describes the image for screen readers - Shows if image fails to load - Helps with SEO **Image formats:** - JPG: Photos - PNG: Graphics with transparency - SVG: Icons and logos (scalable) - WebP: Modern, smaller file sizes

sections.heading: Image as a Link
sections.content: Wrap an image in an anchor tag to make it clickable: ```html ``` This is common for: - Logo links back to homepage - Thumbnail galleries - Call-to-action banners

sections.heading: Embedding Video and Audio
sections.content:
HTML5 introduced native media elements:

```html
<!-- Video -->
<video src="movie.mp4" controls width="640">
    Your browser doesn't support video.
</video>

<!-- Audio -->
<audio src="song.mp3" controls>
    Your browser doesn't support audio.
</audio>

<!-- YouTube embed (iframe) -->
<iframe 
    width="560" 
    height="315" 
    src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/VIDEO_ID"
    allowfullscreen>
</iframe>
```

The `controls` attribute shows play/pause buttons.

forms-and-inputs.title: Forms & User Input
forms-and-inputs.intro: Forms are how users interact with your website - signing up, logging in, searching, submitting feedback. Understanding form elements is essential for building interactive websites.

sections.heading: Basic Form Structure
sections.content:
Every form needs these elements:

```html
<form action="/submit" method="POST">
    <label for="email">Email:</label>
    <input type="email" id="email" name="email" required>
    
    <button type="submit">Submit</button>
</form>
```

- `action`: Where to send the data
- `method`: GET (in URL) or POST (hidden)
- `label`: Describes the input (clickable!)
- `for`/`id`: Connect label to input
- `name`: Identifier for the data

sections.heading: Input Types
sections.content:
HTML5 provides many input types:

```html
<input type="text" placeholder="Your name">
<input type="email" placeholder="email@example.com">
<input type="password">
<input type="number" min="0" max="100">
<input type="tel" placeholder="Phone number">
<input type="date">
<input type="color">
<input type="range" min="0" max="100">
<input type="file" accept="image/*">
<input type="checkbox"> Remember me
<input type="radio" name="choice"> Option 1
```

Using the right type improves:
- Mobile keyboards (email shows @)
- Built-in validation
- Accessibility

sections.heading: Text Areas and Select Menus
sections.content:
For longer text or multiple choices:

```html
<!-- Multi-line text -->
<textarea name="message" rows="4" cols="50">
Default text here
</textarea>

<!-- Dropdown menu -->
<select name="country">
    <option value="">Select a country</option>
    <option value="us">United States</option>
    <option value="uk">United Kingdom</option>
    <option value="ca">Canada</option>
</select>
```

sections.heading: Form Validation
sections.content:
HTML5 provides built-in validation:

```html
<!-- Required field -->
<input type="text" required>

<!-- Minimum/maximum length -->
<input type="text" minlength="3" maxlength="20">

<!-- Pattern matching -->
<input type="text" pattern="[A-Za-z]{3}" 
       title="Three letters only">

<!-- Number range -->
<input type="number" min="18" max="120">
```

The browser shows error messages automatically when validation fails.

semantic-html.title: Semantic HTML & Accessibility
semantic-html.intro: Semantic HTML means using elements that describe their content's meaning, not just its appearance. This makes your sites more accessible, better for SEO, and easier to maintain.

sections.heading: What is Semantic HTML?
sections.content:
Compare these two approaches: **Non-semantic (bad):** ```html
...
...
...
``` **Semantic (good):** ```html
...
...
...
``` Both look the same, but semantic HTML tells browsers and screen readers what each section IS, not just how it looks.

sections.heading: Key Semantic Elements
sections.content:
**Page structure:**
- `<header>`: Introductory content, usually contains logo/nav
- `<nav>`: Navigation links
- `<main>`: The main content (only one per page)
- `<article>`: Self-contained content (blog post, news article)
- `<section>`: Thematic grouping of content
- `<aside>`: Sidebar, related content
- `<footer>`: Footer information

**Text semantics:**
- `<figure>` / `<figcaption>`: Images with captions
- `<time>`: Dates and times
- `<address>`: Contact information
- `<blockquote>`: Quoted content

sections.heading: Why Accessibility Matters
sections.content:
Accessibility (a11y) ensures everyone can use your website:

- **15% of people** have some form of disability
- **Screen readers** rely on semantic HTML
- **Keyboard navigation** needs proper focus states
- **It's often legally required** (ADA, WCAG)

Plus, accessible sites are often better for everyone - clear navigation, readable text, and logical structure benefit all users.

sections.content:

intro-to-css.title: Introduction to CSS
intro-to-css.intro: CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) transforms plain HTML into beautiful, visually engaging websites. While HTML provides structure, CSS controls colors, fonts, spacing, layout, and animations.

sections.heading: What CSS Does
sections.content:
CSS controls every visual aspect of your website:

- **Colors**: Text, backgrounds, borders
- **Typography**: Fonts, sizes, spacing
- **Layout**: Where elements appear on the page
- **Spacing**: Margins, padding, gaps
- **Effects**: Shadows, rounded corners, animations
- **Responsive design**: Different styles for different screen sizes

Without CSS, every website would look like a plain text document from the 90s.

box-model-layout.title: The Box Model & Layout
box-model-layout.intro: Every element in CSS is a box. Understanding the box model is essential for controlling spacing and layout. Once you master this concept, you can position anything on a page.

sections.heading: Understanding the Box Model
sections.content:
Every element has four layers (from inside out):

1. **Content**: The actual text/image
2. **Padding**: Space inside the border
3. **Border**: The edge of the element
4. **Margin**: Space outside the border

```css
.box {
    width: 200px;
    padding: 20px;      /* Inside spacing */
    border: 2px solid black;
    margin: 10px;       /* Outside spacing */
}
```

By default, width/height only set the content size. Padding and border add to the total size!

flexbox.title: Flexbox for Modern Layouts
flexbox.intro: Flexbox revolutionized CSS layout. It makes centering, spacing, and responsive design incredibly easy. Once you learn Flexbox, you'll use it everywhere.

sections.heading: Flexbox Basics
sections.content:
Enable Flexbox on a container: ```css .container { display: flex; } ``` Now all direct children become "flex items" that you can control. ```html
Item 1
Item 2
Item 3
``` By default, items line up in a row and shrink/grow to fit.

sections.heading: Main Axis Alignment
sections.content:
Control horizontal alignment with `justify-content`:

```css
.container {
    display: flex;
    justify-content: flex-start;    /* Left (default) */
    justify-content: center;        /* Center */
    justify-content: flex-end;      /* Right */
    justify-content: space-between; /* Spread out */
    justify-content: space-around;  /* Even spacing */
    justify-content: space-evenly;  /* Equal gaps */
}
```

`space-between` is perfect for navbars and card layouts!

css-grid.title: CSS Grid Basics
css-grid.intro: CSS Grid is the most powerful layout system in CSS. While Flexbox is great for one-dimensional layouts (rows OR columns), Grid excels at two-dimensional layouts (rows AND columns).

sections.heading: Grid Basics
sections.content:
Enable Grid on a container: ```css .container { display: grid; grid-template-columns: 200px 200px 200px; gap: 20px; } ``` This creates a 3-column grid with 200px columns and 20px gaps. ```html
1
2
3
4
5
6
``` Items automatically flow into the grid cells.

sections.heading: Flexible Columns with fr
sections.content:
The `fr` unit divides available space:

```css
.container {
    display: grid;
    grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr;  /* Equal thirds */
    grid-template-columns: 1fr 2fr 1fr;  /* Middle is wider */
    grid-template-columns: 200px 1fr;    /* Fixed + flexible */
}
```

**Repeat shorthand:**
```css
grid-template-columns: repeat(3, 1fr);  /* Three equal columns */
grid-template-columns: repeat(4, 200px); /* Four 200px columns */
```

responsive-design.title: Responsive Design & Media Queries
responsive-design.intro: Responsive design ensures your website looks great on any device - from phones to desktops. With over 50% of web traffic coming from mobile, this skill is essential.

sections.heading: The Viewport Meta Tag
sections.content:
First, ensure proper mobile rendering:

```html
<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
```

This tells mobile browsers to:

intro-to-javascript.title: Introduction to JavaScript
intro-to-javascript.intro: JavaScript brings websites to life. It handles user interactions, updates content dynamically, and powers everything from simple form validation to complex web applications.

sections.heading: What JavaScript Does
sections.content:
JavaScript can:

- **Respond to user actions**: Clicks, scrolls, keyboard input
- **Update content**: Change text, show/hide elements
- **Validate forms**: Check input before submitting
- **Fetch data**: Load content without refreshing the page
- **Create animations**: Smooth transitions and effects
- **Build full applications**: React, Vue, and Angular are all JavaScript

It's the only programming language that runs natively in browsers.

sections.heading: Adding JavaScript to Your Page
sections.content:
Three ways to add JavaScript:

**1. External file (recommended):**
```html
<script src="script.js"></script>
```

**2. Internal script:**
```html
<script>
    console.log('Hello!');
</script>
```

**3. Inline (avoid this):**
```html
<button onclick="alert('Hi!')">Click</button>
```

**Pro tip:** Place scripts at the end of `<body>` or use `defer`:
```html
<script src="script.js" defer></script>
```

sections.heading: Your First JavaScript
The Browser Console
sections.content:
The console is your JavaScript playground:

- **Open it**: F12 or Cmd+Option+I → Console tab
- **Try commands**: Type JavaScript directly and press Enter
- **See errors**: JavaScript errors appear here in red
- **Debug**: Use `console.log()` to inspect values

Try typing these in the console:
```javascript
2 + 2
'Hello'.toUpperCase()
document.title
```

The console is invaluable for learning and debugging.

```javascript
const a = 10;
const b = 3;

// Basic math
a + b;   // 13
a - b;   // 7
a * b;   // 30
a / b;   // 3.333...
a % b;   // 1 (remainder)
a ** b;  // 1000 (power)

// Useful methods
Math.round(3.7);   // 4
Math.floor(3.7);   // 3 (round down)

Math.random();     // Random 0-1

Math.min(1, 5, 3); // 1

// Convert string to number

version-control-git.title: Version Control with Git
version-control-git.intro: Git tracks changes to your code and lets you collaborate with others. Every professional developer uses Git daily. Learning it is essential for any tech career.

sections.heading: What is Git?
sections.content:
Git is a **version control system** that:

- **Tracks changes**: See what changed, when, and why
- **Enables collaboration**: Multiple people can work on the same code
- **Provides backup**: Your code history is saved
- **Allows branching**: Experiment without breaking things

**GitHub** is a website that hosts Git repositories online. It's where most open-source code lives.

sections.heading: Essential Git Commands
sections.content:
```bash
# Setup (one time)
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "you@example.com"

# Start a new repo
git init

# Check status
git status

# Stage changes
git add filename.html    # Specific file
git add .               # All files

# Commit changes
git commit -m "Add homepage layout"

# View history
git log --oneline

# Connect to GitHub
git remote add origin https://github.com/you/repo.git
git push -u origin main
```

sections.heading: The Git Workflow
sections.content:
Daily workflow:

1. **Pull** latest changes: `git pull`
2. **Write** code
3. **Stage** changes: `git add .`
4. **Commit** with message: `git commit -m "message"`
5. **Push** to remote: `git push`

**Good commit messages:**
- "Add contact form validation"
- "Fix navigation bug on mobile"
- "Update homepage hero image"

**Bad commit messages:**
- "fixed stuff"
- "asdf"
- "changes"

sections.heading: Branching Basics
sections.content:
Branches let you work on features separately:

```bash
# Create and switch to new branch
git checkout -b feature/contact-form

# Make changes and commit...

# Switch back to main
git checkout main

# Merge feature branch
git merge feature/contact-form

# Delete branch after merge
git branch -d feature/contact-form
```

This keeps your main branch stable while you experiment.

deploying-your-site.title: Deploying Your Website
deploying-your-site.intro: Your website isn't complete until it's live on the internet! Deployment used to be complex, but modern platforms make it incredibly easy and free.

sections.heading: Deployment Options
sections.content:
Best free hosting platforms for beginners:

**Netlify** (recommended)
- Drag and drop deployment
- Auto-deploys from GitHub
- Free SSL certificates
- Form handling included

**Vercel**
- Great for React/Next.js
- Automatic previews
- Edge network (fast globally)

**GitHub Pages**
- Free for public repos
- Simple static hosting
- Good for portfolios

All three are free for personal projects!

sections.heading: Deploying to Netlify
sections.content:
**Method 1: Drag and Drop**
1. Go to netlify.com and sign up
2. Drag your project folder to the deploy area
3. Done! You get a URL like random-name.netlify.app

**Method 2: Connect GitHub (better)**
1. Push your code to GitHub
2. In Netlify, click "New site from Git"
3. Select your repository
4. Netlify deploys automatically on every push!

**Custom domain:**
1. Go to Site settings → Domain management
2. Add your domain
3. Update DNS at your registrar

sections.heading: Pre-Deployment Checklist
sections.content:
Before going live:

- [ ] Test on multiple browsers (Chrome, Firefox, Safari)
- [ ] Test on mobile devices
- [ ] Check all links work
- [ ] Optimize images (compress them)
- [ ] Add meta tags for SEO
- [ ] Add favicon
- [ ] Test forms if any
- [ ] Check page load speed

```html
<!-- Essential meta tags -->
<meta name="description" content="Your site description">
<meta property="og:title" content="Page Title">
<meta property="og:description" content="Description">
<meta property="og:image" content="preview-image.jpg">
<link rel="icon" href="favicon.ico">
```

sections.heading: After Deployment
sections.content:
Your site is live! Now:

1. **Test the live URL** - Make sure everything works
2. **Share it** - Add to LinkedIn, resume, portfolio
3. **Submit to Google** - Use Google Search Console
4. **Monitor** - Check analytics if interested
5. **Keep improving** - Deploy updates as you learn more

**Celebrate!** You've built and deployed a real website!
